intro: Louichea pteranthus, commonly known as the desert hibiscus, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes hibiscus and cotton. The plant is characterized by its showy, trumpet-shaped flowers that range in color from yellow to red, typically blooming in summer. It has hairy, ribbed stems and lance-shaped leaves that are adapted to conserve water. Louichea pteranthus is drought-tolerant and thrives in well-drained soils, making it a hardy plant suited for xeriscaping.
